response.answer_text: Howdy, Hard? Colt designed a ring pull rifle. Sharps was easy to load…but could you hit your target. Hand guns sound nice…if they work…if you can hit your target. Unlike the movies quarter mile on horseback…you can not hit a barn (if it was standing still). Kentucky rifles were to be mastered, each was hand made, powder varied widely (same with muskets) French used 180 gr powder loads in their muskets. Spanish in Texas would shoot from the hip, resting their muskets on hip or saddle firing (lobbing bullets). Try carrying a 10–15 lb musket, at least a pound of shot, another pound of powder, be sure to have a pound of flints…for a full day in search of game. It is not as easy as it sounds.

Do you mean recoil, weight, poor ergonomics, accuracy? An 1861 Springfield .58 caliber muzzleloader full-length rifled musket, an 1847 Colt Walker 4 pound revolver, an 8 gauge shotgun, a .50–110 1874 Sharps rifle, an English double rifle in elephant-worthy chamberings, a .50 caliber Remington-Ryder single shot pistol, a French LeMat 10 shot revolver, a Colt percussion revolving rifle or shotgun, a Hawkins .54 caliber “Plains” muzzle-loading rifle…those all come to mind.
